articles.headline: Google Could Be Violating Labor Laws With Pay for Temp Workers
articles.snippet: The company realized months ago that it could be running afoul of pay laws in a number of countries but has been slow to fix the problem, according to internal documents.
articles.abstract: The company realized months ago that it could be running afoul of pay laws in a number of countries but has been slow to fix the problem, according to internal documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December, a group of Google managers responsible for overseeing thousands of its temporary staff members discovered the company had been underpaying some of those workers for years.

articles.headline: Times Investigation: In U.S. Drone Strike, Evidence Suggests No ISIS Bomb
articles.snippet: U.S. officials said a Reaper drone followed a car for hours and then fired based on evidence it was carrying explosives. But in-depth video analysis and interviews at the site cast doubt on that account.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials said a Reaper drone followed a car for hours and then fired based on evidence it was carrying explosives. But in-depth video analysis and interviews at the site cast doubt on that account.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was the last known missile fired by the United States in its 20-year war in Afghanistan, and the military called it a “righteous strike” — a drone attack after hours of surveillance on Aug. 29 against a vehicle that American officials thought contained an ISIS bomb and posed an imminent threat to troops at Kabul’s airport.
articles.byline: By Matthieu Aikins, Christoph Koettl, Evan Hill and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Biden’s Sweeping Vaccine Mandates Infuriate Republican Governors
articles.snippet: Some employers and business groups welcomed the new coronavirus requirements, but many G.O.P. leaders issued outright condemnations.
articles.abstract: Some employers and business groups welcomed the new coronavirus requirements, but many G.O.P. leaders issued outright condemnations.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s orders pushing millions of workers to get vaccinated were aimed at turning the tide on a pandemic that has killed 650,000 Americans. But on Friday, the mandates immediately deepened the nation’s political divisions over coronavirus vaccinations and government power.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Richard Fausset and J. David Goodman

articles.headline: 20 Years On, the War on Terror Grinds Along, With No End in Sight
articles.snippet: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.
articles.abstract: The failures in Iraq and Afghanistan obscure what experts say is the striking success of a multilateral effort that extends to as many as 85 countries.

articles.headline: Remembering 9/11
articles.snippet: The weeks and months that followed the attacks were a defining time for many, including on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The weeks and months that followed the attacks were a defining time for many, including on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Anna Schaverien

articles.headline: Always Pay the Rent? It May Help Your Mortgage Application.
articles.snippet: For decades, regular payments to a landlord haven’t counted for much for many tenants trying to get a mortgage. Fannie Mae aims to change that.
articles.abstract: For decades, regular payments to a landlord haven’t counted for much for many tenants trying to get a mortgage. Fannie Mae aims to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: Later this month, a group of renters in the United States will get a new break when they try to become homeowners: Their history of consistently paying their landlords will count toward qualifying for a mortgage.

articles.headline: In Shanksville, Preserving the Memory of 9/11 and the Wars That Followed
articles.snippet: After Flight 93 went down, once unthinkable duties were thrust upon the community, including young people who found themselves coming of age in a time of war.
articles.abstract: After Flight 93 went down, once unthinkable duties were thrust upon the community, including young people who found themselves coming of age in a time of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 20th anniversary of 9/11.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Kristian Thacker

articles.headline: Newsom’s Strategy for California Recall: It’s Me or the Abyss
articles.snippet: Ahead of the vote on Tuesday, the governor is running not so much on his own policies as against the influence of a certain former president.
articles.abstract: Ahead of the vote on Tuesday, the governor is running not so much on his own policies as against the influence of a certain former president.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — As the campaign to oust him heads into its final weekend, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California is hammering home the choice he has presented to voters since the start of the recall — Donald J. Trump or him.

articles.headline: Vaccine Resisters Seek Religious Exemptions. But What Counts as Religious?
articles.snippet: Major denominations are essentially unanimous in their support of the vaccines against Covid-19, but individuals who object are citing their personal faith for support.
articles.abstract: Major denominations are essentially unanimous in their support of the vaccines against Covid-19, but individuals who object are citing their personal faith for support.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Crisann Holmes’s employer announced last month that it would require all employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19 by Nov. 1, she knew she had to find a way out.

articles.headline: A Nick to Apple’s Profits Could Be a Windfall for App Developers
articles.snippet: After a judge opened up a way to avoid Apple’s commission on their sales, companies big and small are seeing dollar signs.
articles.abstract: After a judge opened up a way to avoid Apple’s commission on their sales, companies big and small are seeing dollar signs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has taken to calling its iPhone App Store an “economic miracle,” and it has pointed to developers like Zach Shakked as proof.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Phony Diagnoses Hide High Rates of Drugging at Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: At least 21 percent of nursing home residents are on antipsychotic drugs, a Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: At least 21 percent of nursing home residents are on antipsychotic drugs, a Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: The handwritten doctor’s order was just eight words long, but it solved a problem for Dundee Manor, a nursing home in rural South Carolina struggling to handle a new resident with severe dementia.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas, Robert Gebeloff and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: George Soros Is Making Changes at His Foundation While He Still Can
articles.snippet: The result is a painful restructuring to focus on the fight against rising authoritarianism around the world.
articles.abstract: The result is a painful restructuring to focus on the fight against rising authoritarianism around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mass email that went out to Open Society Foundations’ grant recipients in the United States in March began with an upbeat note about “how resistance is translating into real progress.”

articles.headline: Behind the Texas Abortion Law, a Persevering Conservative Lawyer
articles.snippet: Jonathan Mitchell has never had a high profile in the anti-abortion movement, but he developed and promoted the legal approach that has flummoxed the courts and enraged abortion rights supporters.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Mitchell has never had a high profile in the anti-abortion movement, but he developed and promoted the legal approach that has flummoxed the courts and enraged abortion rights supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan F. Mitchell grew increasingly dismayed as he read the Supreme Court’s decision in June 2016 striking down major portions of a Texas anti-abortion bill he had helped write.

articles.headline: After the 9/11 Attacks, Boston Found a Focus for Its Anger
articles.snippet: Terrorists boarded two planes in Boston and flew them into the World Trade Center. Massachusetts zeroed in on its top airport official, who has never quite recovered.
articles.abstract: Terrorists boarded two planes in Boston and flew them into the World Trade Center. Massachusetts zeroed in on its top airport official, who has never quite recovered.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Virginia Buckingham remembers the moment when she realized that she had been singled out. She had stopped at Dunkin’ Donuts on her way into Logan International Airport, which she oversaw as the top official at the Massachusetts Port Authority. As she stood in line, a man behind her whispered to his friend, “That’s her.”

articles.headline: ‘Black Capitalism’ Promised a Better City for Everyone. What Happened?
articles.snippet: In the wake of nationwide protests, corporate America has pledged to fight racism and support Black Americans. But a similar initiative started decades ago in Rochester shows it is a promise that is difficult to sustain.
articles.abstract: In the wake of nationwide protests, corporate America has pledged to fight racism and support Black Americans. But a similar initiative started decades ago in Rochester shows it is a promise that is difficult to sustain.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — The Panther Graphics printing plant sits along a row of red brick buildings and empty parking lots on the edge of a circular highway that separates this city’s downtown from a largely Black neighborhood to the north. Nearby, there is a warehouse, a Baptist Church and a billboard that warns “A Shot from A Gun Can’t Be Undone,” a reference to Rochester’s soaring murder rate.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Photographs By Todd Heisler

articles.headline: G.O.P. Seethes at Biden Mandate, Even in States Requiring Other Vaccines
articles.snippet: Resistance to vaccine mandates, once a fringe position, has entered the Republican mainstream. But the governors fighting President Biden’s Covid-19 requirements impose mandates of their own.
articles.abstract: Resistance to vaccine mandates, once a fringe position, has entered the Republican mainstream. But the governors fighting President Biden’s Covid-19 requirements impose mandates of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Like other Republican governors around the country, Tate Reeves of Mississippi reacted angrily to the coronavirus vaccine mandates President Biden imposed on private businesses. Declaring the move “terrifying,” he wrote on Twitter: “This is still America, and we still believe in freedom from tyrants.”

articles.headline: False Election Claims in California Reveal a New Normal for G.O.P.
articles.snippet: In an echo of 2020, Republicans are pushing baseless allegations of cheating in the state’s recall race even before Election Day.
articles.abstract: In an echo of 2020, Republicans are pushing baseless allegations of cheating in the state’s recall race even before Election Day.
articles.lead_paragraph: The results of the California recall election won’t be known until Tuesday night. But some Republicans are already predicting victory for the Democrat, Gov. Gavin Newsom, for a reason that should sound familiar.

articles.headline: The Legacy of America’s Post-9/11 Turn to Torture
articles.snippet: Twenty years after the attacks, the United States is still grappling with the consequences of brutal interrogations carried out in the name of national security.
articles.abstract: Twenty years after the attacks, the United States is still grappling with the consequences of brutal interrogations carried out in the name of national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania — Mohamedou Ould Slahi is almost clinical as he recalls details of the torture he endured in the summer of 2003 at Guantánamo Bay.

articles.headline: Why Our Monsters Talk to Michael Wolff
articles.snippet: In his new book, the author of “Fire and Fury” continues his specialty: teasing out stories from men in power.
articles.abstract: In his new book, the author of “Fire and Fury” continues his specialty: teasing out stories from men in power.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s early 2019, a few months before Jeffrey Epstein will be arrested on sex charges, and he is sitting in the vast study of his New York mansion with a camera pointed at him as he practices for a big “60 Minutes” interview that would never take place.

articles.headline: Abortion Is No Longer a Crime in Mexico. But Will Doctors Object?
articles.snippet: Another battle looms over whether public hospitals will be required to offer the procedure.
articles.abstract: Another battle looms over whether public hospitals will be required to offer the procedure.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — As soon as the nurse found out that she had an abortion at home, Fernanda García knew she was in danger. The nurse began yelling that she was a criminal, that what she had done was wrong, that she would be sent to jail.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez

articles.headline: Can a Green-Economy Boom Town Be Built to Last?
articles.snippet: The race to make electric vehicles is turning some places into winners. Normal, Ill., is one of them. But it has seen good times go sour in the past.
articles.abstract: The race to make electric vehicles is turning some places into winners. Normal, Ill., is one of them. But it has seen good times go sour in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORMAL, Ill. — When he bought a construction contractor called Weber Electric in 2018, Josh Mosier inherited about 20 employees. By the end of the next year, he was up to about 100 employees. By the spring of 2021, the number was over 225.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Akilah Townsend

articles.headline: In California, Republicans Struggle to Expand the Recall’s Appeal
articles.snippet: California has not been as progressive lately as its reputation would suggest. Yet Republicans have had trouble breaking the recall out of the fringe.
articles.abstract: California has not been as progressive lately as its reputation would suggest. Yet Republicans have had trouble breaking the recall out of the fringe.
articles.lead_paragraph: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — The small faction of Californians who still call themselves Republicans did something seemingly impossible when they forced Gavin Newsom, the Democratic governor of America’s largest Democratic state, to face voters in a recall.

articles.headline: Britain Prepared for a Jobs Crisis, Just Not the One It Got
articles.snippet: Instead of a surge in unemployment, businesses are struggling to fill positions, presenting a new risk to the pandemic recovery.
articles.abstract: Instead of a surge in unemployment, businesses are struggling to fill positions, presenting a new risk to the pandemic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Empty beer taps in pubs, supermarkets low on Diet Coke, milkshakes missing at McDonald’s: It seems each new day in Britain brings a new notice of scarce products and services as businesses are waylaid by the country’s shortage of truck drivers and other workers.

articles.headline: ‘Their Crisis’ Is ‘Our Problem’: Washington Grapples With Idaho Covid Cases
articles.snippet: Hospitals in Washington State, already strained, are taking on an influx of Covid patients from Idaho, where the governor has refused to require masks or vaccinations.
articles.abstract: Hospitals in Washington State, already strained, are taking on an influx of Covid patients from Idaho, where the governor has refused to require masks or vaccinations.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
